I'd build some trust beforehand. Talk to her a couple of times before asking her out so you're not total strangers to each other.
The biggest factor in increasing your chances is good timing. You should get to know her enough so that she's not a complete stranger, but not so much that she's become a friend. Then you must be upfront and not hesitant, make it clear that you're asking her out, and don't try to mask it as a friendly outing to increase your chances. If she likes you, she'll probably say yes, and if she doesn't like you, you can't really do much about it.

Conversations through text can very easily bore someone.

Other times the conversation flows so naturally it's perfect.
It's a matter of chance really. Someone out there will enjoy conversations with you and others will send 1 message and never reply. Just it what it is.
Now if you tell me that literally every single woman has left you on read, you might want to switch up how you talk through text. Keep it light hearted and throw in jokes/memes without trying too hard.

I seriously hope you guys don't do this. Until you get a firm commitment from her, literally never do this.

I had the exact same experience last summer. I was traveling in Europe and hadn't expected to meet girls from a similar cultural background to mine. But I did, and when we went on our first date it felt so right. We talked for three hours over drinks, it was past midnight before she had to leave (we met on a Sunday). It felt natural. I came away from the first date thinking I had found the one. I'm not normally that way.

I didn't WANT to talk to other girls either, to keep swiping on Tinder. But as we got back to our lives, I kept thinking about her more and more, and I felt the urge to talk to her constantly.

It didn't help that I wasn't in a good place; I had just lost my job (I worked remotely) and needed someone to help prop me up. Even when I had that job, I wasn't in a good place mentally.

If I had friends where I was, or was dating other women, I wouldn't have been so pathetic. I wouldn't have been so attached. I think it came across in my energy as desperation.

I texted her the day after our first date. The conversation fizzled, and she stopped responding after a few hours. I met her in the middle of the week to return something she had forgotten on our first date. She said she was very busy and we only talked for about a half hour.

I think she was seeing other men. I never saw her again. She kept blowing me off when I asked when she wanted to hang out. The point of it all is you should assume she's seeing other people, and you should do that as well to minimize how attached you are. You should never assume she's yours until she actually is, it'll save you a lot of heartbreak. Dating is brutal these days. To stop seeing other people without knowing that she'll do the same is unilateral disarmament.

>If I'm talking on an app and the conversation is feeling dry and she's giving short, curt responses do I continue trying to goad her into talking or just give up?
Your goal talking on an app should be to get her to agree to a date as soon as possible. Before that, you need to have a short conversation that feels right enough for her to do that. Can't be too short that she feels rushed, can't be too long that it get stale and she gets distracted by the constant barrage of stimuli in contemporary life.

There's no use in trying to keep up a protracted conversation on Tinder. She'll inevitably get bored and find something else to do. Obviously, I'm not saying to blow her off if you happen to have a conversation that flows and feel natural, and she's responsive. But you do need to keep in mind that your only objective is to get her to meet in person as soon as that's feasible.

You need to remember you're liable to be disposed at a moment's notice until you get out of the Tinder zone. The only way out of the Tinder zone is by fucking her. Then you become a real person, an honest-to-God part of their life. All Tinder advice is ultimately about getting to this point as soon as possible without making it feel rushed or forced or like you're trying too hard.

The vibe that I'm getting from this post is that you seek reassurance.

I think your problem is you're too eager for happiness. You see having a woman by your side as the fastest path to getting that happiness (and you're probably right). The problem is this is making you needy. It probably comes off that way in your dealings with women. It's desperate. And nothing turns a woman off faster than desperation.

My advice to you would be to make peace with how monotonous and boring and unfulfilling daily life is. Try to find ways to mitigate these things without a woman's help: make guy friends, hang out with your guy friends more often, take an interest in your career, develop hobbies that occupy your time. Develop emotional strength.

You don't need to be happy, but you do need to learn to be satisfied with your life the way it is. That's how you develop confidence. That's how you keep from falling all over yourself whenever the first woman to let you get a whiff of her minge comes along. She'll respect you a lot more for it. Without respect, there can't be sex, love, or even friendship.

Eat healthy.
Wash your hair regularly.
Keep your hands clean. Don't touch your face.
Wash your bedding and pillowcases weekly. Monthly if you're a lazy fuck.

Np, man.
I don't think there are any methods to 'patch up' wrinkles, unfortunately. As far as I'm aware, your only option for fixing existing wrinkles is filler injections.
>don't judge filler too harshly, btw. We think of filler as 'gross bimbo lip filler', but in most cases, it's natural-looking and invisible. Filler is the victim of bad advertising. If you notice it, it's done wrong.

Realistically, all you can do right now is avoid FUTURE wrinkling.
Whether you develop wrinkles is largely genetic, but taking good care of your skin in the sun (applying sunscreen appropriately and avoiding the sun where possible) is important. Eating healthy (certain fruits and vegetables are great for your skin) and drinking plenty of water is good for preventing wrinkles. And I think you can purchase creams that help your skin to avoid future wrinkling. Idk how they work, and desu the cosmetics industry makes a lot of dubious claims, but these may potentially help.

Why are you whining like a little bitch? I have a baby grand piano in a room next to our dining room and I call it the piano room. My wife says we could move the piano to the living room, and use the room for something else. I said no, politely.

She insisted. And every time she asked, I’d smile and say “no darling”. No reason to get angry or lose your bitch-tits milk. It’s simple - “no” - end of story.

One day my wife moved the piano to the living room with the help of her sister’s husband. When I got home, my in-laws and my wife along with our kids said “surprise! A new place for the piano!”

I simply said “If you could all please leave, I have to have a word with my wife”. Everyone left so I asked why she moved my piano. She explained her reasoning. I said “fair enough”.

The next day I contacted a contractor and the local piano company. I started a project to increase the size of the piano room into the dining room, making it substantially smaller. At first the wife was aghast, but then she grew interested in the size of the new room.

3 weeks later the project was done and the former piano room was now massive. So I scheduled a pick up for my baby piano. When the wife asked if I was getting rid of it, I said yes.

Three days after that my new Steinway & Sons model A grand piano arrived, and was assembled and tuned in my new Piano room.

The wife, beside herself, asked why.
>Just following your lead and making decisions you don’t agree with
That’s that.

Ok, radical ideas incoming.
Talk to her adult to adult.
Let her know she's loved, and ask why she's so insecure and unable to trust you.
She may say that she's the one with trust issues, knowing it's irrational etc etc... and this is where the aduly part comes in.
It is not fair for you to be judged based on her experience with other people. It's understandable, vut bot fair. It also doesn't have to be a big deal. You might try pointing that out and gently letting her know that your expectation is that she will stop putting other people's decisions on your shoulders and judge you FOR you, not for her exes or her expectations.
Standing up for yourself doesn't have to be a fight. Done right, it's a chance to show leadership, headship. Refusing to accept a partner's bad behavior is a very positive thing.
Ultimately, with an immature woman, it will usually go according to a script about poor her, her past, etc etc. This is very manipulative and a trap. If you are sympathetic but firm, it will be an opportunity to grow.

We've got a unicorn here. Some genuinely solid, healthy advice on /adv/.

OP, you've straight-up just gotta be honest with her. Anxiety isn't something that she chose, but how she chooses to deal with her anxiety is definitely her choice. If her behaviour is becoming a problem for you, communicate that to her and let her know what you need from her. In return, ask her how you can help her to make the changes that you need to see from her. Of course, she will have to battle her anxiety to adjust her own behaviour, and that's gonna be rough. Have some patience with her.

Uh, I'd be very firm about that "she thought I was cheating because I didn't reply to her" shit though. That's absolutely not ok. You're gonna want to shut that kind of shit down hard.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Here's a quick rundown about quitting alcohol using medication. I did 3 rehabs for it along with trying A.A. multiple times. Didn't help much.

Naltrexone for addiction treatment

Addicts have impulses that drive them back to certain behaviors. Understanding that the behavior is harmful, along with a resolve to quit frequently is not enough, because the powerful urge or cravings exist far apart from rational thinking. Worth noting is that gambling, sex, compulsive overeating, alcoholism and drug addiction are a cluster of similar disorders: a malfunction of the brain's "reward center". See for yourself: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18241634/

Naltrexone is a helpful medication to remove the cravings. Classed as an opiate-antagonist (binds to endorphin receptors w/out "high"), Naltrexone comes in a once-monthly injection or daily pills. Absent insurance, injection is expensive and pills are inexpensive. Public health clinics, aka "community clinics" receive federal and state cost-reduction grants to serve people who lack insurance. Sliding-fee scale for most services and in the case of Naltrexone injection, often free. In the U.S. you can call 211 in most cities, a direct line to United Way. They will help you locate such a clinic. Also some anti-depressants and other psychotropic medications can help. Addicts tend to have mood or other psychiatric issues that are called "co-morbid factors". A doctor at a "community clinic" can help with that also. Naltrexone is typically taken daily for 3+ months.

Drugs.com has 500+ positive reviews about Naltrexone from actual alcoholics.

"Medical detox" refers to a doctor prescribing librium or valium for a few days to get you safely off alcohol. It works and its painless. Trying to "taper down" WITH alcohol is slow and extremely painful. Most doctors will readily offer you a medical detox prescription.

Can you get quickly into neuro surgery OP?

Think about it a bit.

That 24 week cyber security course is either pretty basic or an addon to people with experience in the industry.

In order to even begin dabbling in cyber security at all you should become at the very least adept or very good at the following:

Networking
Application security
Security practices
Virtualization

And extremely familiar with the way operating systems work

Even with this, you will be scraping bottom tier jobs in this field until you acquire great amount of experience as most serious companies only take in seniors for this role type.

Go finish Aspens CND/Ethical Hacker/Pen test certifications, since companies would actually consider you with those certifications. My husband works and I'm taking care of housework. My husband had a dog before we met, a female collie mix of some kind, who I'm admittedly a little afraid of. She's a much bigger dog than I'm accustomed to being around, but I'm taking care of her throughout the day in addition to normal chores.

At night when my husband gets home, he's understandably tired from work so I take the dog out to potty before bed. We live in a mixed area though, and our neighbors have been pretty aggressive and even fighting each other once in a while. I don't really feel safe trying to control this big dog on a walk in the first place, and in the dark around unpredictable people with an animal I don't feel like I have full control over is not my idea of a good night.

I want to ask if he can take over walking her after he's home from work every night, but I feel guilty about pushing a chore off on him when he's already working earlier in the day. I kind of worry the neighbors might bother me though, or that the dog might bother them. Would it be selfish of me to ask if he'd be up for taking over that chore?

Every relationship is different, so I don't know if we can offer advice for your unique relationship. The correct answer is whatever you both agree to that you can mutually tolerate to continue the marriage happily and without resentment. It's a deal you make with each other based on what you can tolerate, and if he's a good husband he'll be sensitive to this complaint of yours, but I don't know him and he may not be open to it. It sounds like he works and you're a stay-at-home spouse, which is a foreign concept to me. I can't eliminate the possibility that he'll be a big baby about it, if not straight up abusive, but that's just me assuming things about you both.

If you're living that 1950s dream, he will probably be a little not happy about working and walking the dog. But it's his dog, he should be taking care of it. My wife and I split chores and we both work. It's equitable and we're fine, neither of us feels resentment for having to do more. Sorry if that came off harsh or judgy, but it's the truth.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Meeting people used to be the easiest thing in the world. People had neighborhoods. Their family knew other families. Young people didn't splinter across the country and become alone. Huge communities where multi-generational families were friends. Everyone knew eachother.

Now, in pursuit of office jobs, everything got fractured. Isolated, segmented, decentralized. Now, loneliness is one of the most common ailments. "How do I meet people?" would have got you laughed at 50 years ago. People spent a lot of time with other people. The point of this rant is that its not so much your fault, or anyone else on this board who posts the same exact thing 50 times per day. It's a massive phenomenon. Many people suffering alone.

You have to look at any job application from the employers perspective. What is it that YOU can bring to THEM? How does hiring YOU benefit THEM? And here's the clincher, how does the benefits YOU bring stack up against or compete with ALL THE OTHER CANDIDATES?

Btw, "they get an employee" is not an answer to that question. So you need to start at the absolute bottom in a shithole dead end job where they need employee scale but face high turnover so basically everyone who applies gets hired. That's where you need to focus your applications. Build up some work experience over 18 months and you'll be in a much better position to get employed somewhere else.

Remember, a paper qualification is meaningless in 2023 without experience.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28101153
A job change isn't going to fix your life. You need an entire lifestyle change. I'm 26 and went through something similar around 24. I'm going to recommend something cliche, but it fucking works for reasons I will elaborate on. Get in shape. If you are fat lose weight. If you are skinny hit the gym. Yes it's a physical thing but we are mostly after the mental benefits. When you improve physically it does several things mentally (arguably it has more mental benefits than physical). First is you learn to be disciplined. This obviously effects every aspect of life. You need discipline to escape NEETdom. Next it will give you a taste of that "better life". You will see hard effort turn into tangible rewards that you can be proud of. This can set off a chain reaction into other aspects of life you feel are lacking. Next is confidence. You will be more confident in your self and your abilities and it could be enough of a boost to get you to pounce on opportunities you otherwise would have missed by being passive. Perhaps most important of all it will get you out of the house and give you a hobby that isn't doing anything for you. This can lead to meeting new people and gives you a common interest hobby that you can share and engage with most people over. Don't forget other people will treat you better too.

All of that doesn't even take into account the physical aspects that also play a role in mental health. You would likely see an increase in certain hormones such as testosterone and a decrease in things like estrogen. These hormones play a huge role in mental health and having screwed up hormones probably play a huge role in depression and the like. In my opinion physical improvement is the number one best thing you can do if you are unhappy with your life because it lays the foundation for everything else. This is coming from someone who was fat basically my entire life and was well on my way to being an eternal neet. Getting /fit/ is what saved me.

>>28176244
I can't read it. My specific situation will not really relate to you.

The TL;DR is that I am an /out/ist through and through and nothing is going to change that.

I was in the army before college. Biology degree. Wildly depressed, and medicated for it. In college I did an internship with a conservation agency and it was fun, but I did the "right thing" and after school I just kept pursuing my "career path." Nothing glamorous or financially enticing, mind you. At 27 I had a paradigm shift, some major life changes (sister offed herself and ended a toxic 6 year relationship) and I took some seasonal /out/ work in Alaska to try and clear my heart and my head. Quit taking Zoloft during this time.

Following this, I left and did a "normal" job for about 1.25 years before I again felt the urge to get the fuck back outside. I worked for an environmental compliance contractor. I had a moment of clarity when a guy who had been there for 12 years told me he had a zoology degree. It made me sad to know he once shared my dreams. So I had to leave. Almost every person I knew told me that, at ~28 it was too late for a "career change" and I should just stay in place and effectively work at the same place until I died. I've since worked for a few different agencies/places for the feds doing /out/ things. I do not make much money. My job security is tenuous. But I feel at peace and wouldn't change it.

The point of my story is simply that if you recognize something you are truly passionate about, you should just stick with it, because trying to convince yourself you are happier in some other capacity just results in you being miserable. I wouldn't do something just to feel like you're moving forward, if that makes sense. I wouldn't do something you aren't "super passionate" about. Do not go be a cop simply because it is SOMETHING. Its your life, anon. 1/4 of it is over. Do you want to waste another 1/2 doing something you don't even give a shit about?

Step two is employment, which mostly sucks. Some people will tell you about how they have a passion for making other people rich, but they're mostly just coping. The purpose of employment is to GET CASH FLOW so you can either exit employment or at least have the funds to cope with it and stay sane. You should find something you're good at that you can tolerate without burning out that MAXIMIZES cash flow and pursue that. Ideally it should pay you to learn skills that you can deploy outside of employment so you can exit employment sooner rather than later. Think of employment as a bridge from virgin neetdom to chad neetdom. Some examples of viable options are trades, sales, it, coding meme, internet marketing. You can get an entry-level job in most of these fields with little-to-no experience. Grind certs, lie, just do whatever you need to do. Then start accruing skills that you can use for freelancing, consulting, contracting, ect in order to exit employment. If you really want to you can do your art fag stuff on the side, and if that blows up and you stop showing up to your job, more power to you.

>>28203127
This >>28203241
Also, mood swings are felt mostly because of uncertainty. The more confused you are, the more often you will feel it. You need clarity on your career and your social relationships with friends, family, and closed ones.

For example, you meet a person, get along with him for quite some time, and for one reason or another, you start feeling confused about if you can continue asking him out or play it subtly and wait for him to ask you out sometimes.

You will face this kind of situation more often where your subconscious won’t be able to decide what your next step should be and when you won’t get clarity on such things, you will most likely be trying such things which you don’t intend to.

To handle this, make your mind clear on such topics that seem important but are not. You do have other important things to focus on, why to waste both your time and energy on such things. One piece of advice which I would like you to consider is, “Leave it! or Let it be!”. Your friend is ignoring you, let it be. Your sibling is getting more attention, let it be. Your less deserving colleague is getting a promotion, let it be. I am sure this “Mantra” will help you prioritize things.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28204689
>Confidence is not separable from self-esteem.
It is.

I use to do a lot of amateur drama, and before a performance I was always nervous as hell. I know perfectly well I could give a good performance, but I was still overcome with worries: What if one of the lights falls down and kills someone in the audience? What if <other person> blows their lines and skips an entire scene, are we going to be able to recover from that in time? What if the blood pack bursts before I'm supposed to be shot? When I was actually *on* stage I was fine, of course.

But there is an important difference between thinking "I'm going to be shit" and being overwhelmed by worries about things that theoretically could go wrong, many of which aren't even anything to do with you.

Shyness is often more like the second one. It's about irrational anxiety, not about something you regard as a perfectly rational concern about yourself.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>28203012
>But when someone says their hobby is history, wtf am I supposed to talk/ask about?
Favorite time period and why. GO!
Segways into more than just names and dates and you can fit other topics into the conversation like art, literature, political movements, geological events, etc.
>I like to read new material, learn about disorders, the brain, etc. but how should I use this knowledge in a conversation?
Unless the conversation turns to it, just keep it in the back of your head. You don't want to be the "insert random factoid at odd times" guy. If you really want to talk about it, find groups with similar interests. If they don't have similar interests, you can talk about an intersectional interest, like any periodicals that people read or videos they like to watch. That coaxes a conversation that can be mutually beneficial, they can talk about what they are interested in and like to learn about and ditto from you. The hard part is entry into the conversation, but once you're in, you should be set if you can keep the conversation going.
It's basically a topic game of shiritori.
>How do you guys do it?
Beats me. I am a lurker by nature, so I just watch and learn from others while I quietly sit/stand in the corner and listen in on conversations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>But when someone says their hobby is history, wtf am I supposed to talk/ask about?
Ask them how they got into it. Or if there’s a particular time period they’re into. Or whether they have a university education on it or if it’s something they pursue on their own. Is there a particularly big community around the hobby? Are they a part of it? Do they have any favorite… things related to their hobby? (In this case, historical figures, periods, events)

It’s something you have to judge on a case-by-case basis depending on the
hobby, but those are some general questions that should serve you well regardless. People like being asked to elaborate on their interests.

Think about what YOU would like to be asked about psychology or vidya. That might help you come up with some more general questions to ask.

As for divulging your own interests, you gotta wait for somebody to ask about them to open up. If they don’t ask, don’t talk about it, because they don’t care. Only give as much information as they ask for, and don’t just spew out facts about psychology.

When it comes to talking with other psych nerds I can’t really help you there. I don’t like talking about my interests with people into the same thing. Seems to always turn into an argument or an awkward circlejerk about information we both already know.

First of all, don't change to be someone else that's not your truly self just to impress or get something you desire because it can have a huge drawback in the long term. It's also important to remember that everyone has their own unique communication style and it's okay if you're not as expressive as others.

It sounds like you're struggling to express yourself and connect with the ladies. That's a tough spot to be in, but don't worry, it can be improved. One way to do this is by setting small goals for yourself in social situations. Like, try to start a convo with one new chick at a party or share a personal story or opinion in a group setting. As you accomplish these goals, you'll build confidence and feel more comfortable expressing yourself.

Another tip is to focus on active listening, like really pay attention to what the girl is saying and respond in a way that shows you're engaged in the convo. This can help to build a deeper connection and open up more opportunities for you to express yourself.

Remember, confidence is something that you can build and improve over time, so don't be too hard on yourself and keep pushing yourself out of your comfort zone.

Hey there anon, I totally get where you're coming from. Moving to a new country can be a huge change and it's totally normal to feel a bit overwhelmed. But I want you to know that you've got this desu!

Here's my advice to you :3: Talk openly with your relative about what you need and what your expectations are for living together. That way, you can ensure that you have a positive living experience. Also, take things one step at a time. Don't try to change everything about yourself at once. Just focus on small goals and build on them as you get more comfortable in your new surroundings. And most importantly, don't be afraid to step out of your comfort zone and try new things. It's a great opportunity for you to grow and become more independent. And remember, it's totally normal to feel homesick, give yourself time and be kind to yourself. Best of luck!

Mail Carrier here. In the long term, it pays very well for how simple the job is. You get frequent raises and after 13 years, you'll be making as much as managerial positions. Starting pay is nothing to sneeze at either.

Once you get past your 90 day probationary period, you will not be fired unless you do something foolish like steal mail. You won't get laid off either which makes it much better than the private sector in terms of stability.

The world will always need deliverers anon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28202972
You forgot about the two-tier system that favors boomers and the mandatory overtime plus 6 day workweek for non-careers. It depends on the individual post office, but you'll likely be working 6 days, 10+ hour days every week until you hit career. Even when you hit career, they can still fuck around with you such as mandating overtime due to a bs emergency. There's also a wage ceiling, which basically puts you at a max-out GS-10.
If you get a college degree, you can get a real federal job where you only work 5 days, 40 hours a week, and after 10-15 years become a GS-13, GS-14, GS-15 and make at least $110k without 6 day workweeks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28201066
Yes, but don't walk in thinking you're better than this. If you want to work for the USPS, realize that means working every day, 60 hours a week if not more. It's not just a job, from now on your entire life revolves around delivering the mail. It takes a certain kind of person and your coworkers will be immediately trying to figure out if you're 'one of them'. You might think you're quick, better get 4X faster, your fingers need to be reading those addresses before your eyes even see them.

On your shadow day, write down everyone's names when you get a chance. After 90 working days, as long as you try to do a good job; you're basically guaranteed to be a mailman for life. The pay isn't great, but it's better than worrying about getting laid off if you want to have a family.

Do you really think you're so interesting that the government or some other powerful entity has taken an interest in your daily life?People stare anon, especially the elderly since they're more likely to not give a fuck. Moreso if you look like a paranoid schizo.

Fiction shapes our reality. That's why shortly after the first UFO movies there were so many flying saucer sightings. There's a good documentary about it on YouTube or something. The objective truth is that we don't have the technology to be putting cameras in people's eyes, except for the one guy who had it done where it's blatantly obvious it's a camera. Furthermore, we don't live in Soviet Russia. People don't have the kind of allegiance to their government that gets them to give up an eye (and we definitely don't have the technology to connect a camera directly to the optic nerve, so double robotic eyes are out).

The human mind is more plastic than you think. Lengthy police interrogations have led to suspects fabricating memories and giving false confessions, even when they know they didn't do a thing. I believe the fastest way to alter memory is fear, so try not to live in fear, as that will make it all the more real in your mind. I personally have no experience with stuff like your case but I'm told ignoring it or recognizing/believing it isn't real can help for reasons already stated.

The sooner you acknowledge this as a figment of your imagination, the better. Whether you seek professional help is up to you, as long as you aren't at risk of harming yourself or others, but I hope for your sake you do. You're looking for patterns in things that are essentially completely random. This is another wonder of the human brain: pattern recognition. Thinking evolutionarily, it's more beneficial to be paranoid and see a face where there isn't one, than not seeing one that intends to kill you. Thinking numerically, it's almost guaranteed for there to be some pattern in say, a phone book, just due to the sheer amount of randomness. You will find patterns, but only ones which are meaningless.

The robot eyes might be your mind perceiving those people as untrustworthy or shady, so that could lead to your people avoiding them. As for your dog, it sounds like there is no pattern other than her recognizing that there is a person and being either curious or skittish.

Doctors can't force you to take medication as long as you don't tell them you intend to bring harm to yourself or others. >>28195736
>Does suffering actually build character?
If you experience suffering for a long time, you will not be the same human. Either you will become better or bitter, or both. It all depends on what you do or how you react to the suffering.

I don't think most suffering is the kind that produces deep trauma. The kind of trauma that does not build character. Generally anything valuable that isn't immediate gratification requires some amount of suffering or sacrifice in order to obtain, for example. And most of that isn't traumatic.

It's also important to note that character is the prerequisite for suffering.

But it could be to the extent that you have to grow in order to stop suffering. So when you have managed to see reality in a way that a situation that previously made you suffer doesn't anymore. That's Growth.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Some good replies already here.
Nietzsche says that pain doesn't make you better but it does make you more profound. Obviously there are degrees of pain, and it depends on what you do with it/if you can recover from it.
I'd argue that if you can recover from it you'll be stronger and even more "interesting". Hard part is that even if you manage to recover you'll still be very different than you were beforehand so learning to enjoy yourself again is another challenge, albeit smaller than your initial issue.

>Different leftists believe different things about gender, but they usually define gender as something separate but related to sex.
Gender was unanimously considered another term for sex until the 1950s with the rise of post modernists like Simone De Beauvoir and psychologists like John Money tried making the distinction. No compelling evidence for gender identity exists.
>Okay, but when an intersex person is born with a “deformity” they still get assigned male or female (usually female) Why is this?
Because of gamete production. Biological sex is not determined by chromosomes or phenotypic expression. When a person is born intersex, they are born with one set of working parts and never the other. There has never been a case of true hermaphrodism in humans.

>Sexologist John Money is often regarded as the first to introduce a terminological distinction between biological sex and gender role (which, as originally defined, includes the concepts of both gender role and what would later become known as gender identity) in 1955[10][11] although Madison Bentley had already in 1945 defined gender as the "socialized obverse of sex",[12][13] and Simone de Beauvoir's 1949 book The Second Sex has been interpreted as the beginning of the distinction between sex and gender in feminist theory.[14][15]

>Before Money's work, it was uncommon to use the word gender to refer to anything but grammatical categories.[3][1] However, Money's meaning of the word did not become widespread until the 1970s, when feminist theory embraced the concept of a distinction between biological sex and the social construct of gender. Most contemporary social scientists,[16][17][18] behavioral scientists and biologists,[19] many legal systems and government bodies,[20] and intergovernmental agencies such as the WHO,[21] make a distinction between gender and sex.

>In other contexts, the term gender has been used as a synonym for sex without representing a clear conceptual difference. For instance, in non-human animal research, gender is commonly used to refer to the biological sex of the animals.[1] This change in the meaning of gender can be traced to the 1980s. In 1993, the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) started to use gender instead of sex to avoid confusion with sexual intercourse.[22]

Funny seeing this post, I waited tables not too long ago for a while and I liked it so much I'm wrestling with the idea of going back to it even though I don't need the money.

>Any tips or information I should know before trying?

Working in a restaurant can be very stressful. When it's busy they got you running around all over the place with todo list that somehow always get longer throughout the night. The one thing that helps me deal with that sort of stress is to always bring my mind back to the present task. You can only do one thing at a time so make sure to do it right, then move on to the next thing. "One thing at a time" became kind of a mantra after some times lol

>I'm a guy, do girls get more money in tips?

There's plenty of tips to go around, just gotta find your crowd. Sure, a group of dads might tip more if they get served by a young lady but the opposite is also true for a group of moms ;)

>Will I end up meeting people and making new friends or is that all a big lie?

Basically, spending time together + stress equals good friends.

>Any tips or information I should know before trying?

one lass piece of info for ya, the cooks are probably gonna be assholes, doesnt matter what you look like, so don't take it personally. Also, YOU WILL mess up with your orders sometimes so when you need some bullshit meal prepared on the fly, it's good to be cool with the kitchen people

Statistically, both the length of time in a relationship before marriage and the age at marriage are related to divorce. Iirc, for time spent dating, most of the divorce-related instability is gone after 2 years, and almost all of it is eliminated by waiting 3. The optimal ages are around 24 to remove most of the age-related instability and around 29 to completely eliminate it.
These data points obviously come with a lot of caveats, since they don't exist in isolation. A couple who met at 18 should statistically wait a few more years, because their youth is the dominant risk. On the other hand, insisting that a woman spend her entire youth (i.e. until she's around 29) before you even consider marriage with her is grossly unfair for a marginal increase in stability, if any.

Not to mention that HOW people date is an even bigger factor most of the time. For example, if they get into a string of sexual relationships that fail for one reason or another, the odds of divorce increase significantly. Having any more than one sexual partner (very likely if you have sex without being married) is responsible for most of this.

I'll feel good for a brief second, then remember "Oh, that girl who said she loved you and wanted a family with you, ran off with another dude." Or just some other shit.

How do I dig myself out of the depression hole? I'm willing to work, it just doesn't feel like anything I do is working. Normally I'd tell myself to just kind of tough through it, and bring myself up by the bootstraps, but I've been doing that the past 6 months, and I don't feel too much better.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28201527
Finding a therapist or group therapy you can stand is worth it for at least a few months. You dont have to take meds. It does help to speak on it without fear of consequences.

Seek family. Friends. A preacher or sibling. As embarrassing as you feel ask someone if your can speak to them for a whole about how shit you been feeling.

Nature helps me often. The depression comes and goes. Its been sitting on me heavier lately but I am older and have found what works for me to fight it.

Helping others helps too. If you cant humble yourself to seek help from others help someone. Make it a goal to help someone near you regardless of how helpless and bitter a person they are. Do it for no reason. Help your mom genuinely for no good reason just start making dinners for her and doing more chores. Go mow some old guys lawn and listen to him bitch at you about zoomers and fix his printer. Doing this isnt gonna make you instantly happy theres no magic chemical bump of sorts in the brain. But you can hate yourself less of you are at least genuinely nicer and more helpful even if its forced and feels fake.

posts.com:
>>28202368
I have noticed this as well and talked about it.
Improving one's personality is often treated as a throw-away line. "Oh, go work on yourself." It is meant dismissively. People don't generally give advice on how to actually be a better person.
What is meant, if anything is meant at all besides an insult, is that you should foster personality treats conducive to being sociable and likable. For example, traits like gregarious, honest, trusting, groomed, kind, patient, and so on. These traits make people like you more, generally speaking.
Conversely, you can approach it from the other direction. Instead of fostering positive traits ("virtues"), you can remove negative traits. Traits like wrathful, cruel, proud, shy, paranoid, and envious are all anti-social and, generally, make people like you less - unless they themselves also have the trait (e.g. shy people like shy people).
That being said, some traits can be useful, even if they are "anti-social." For instance, being paranoid can help alert you to danger or being wrathful helps you be a better fighter. It is up to you to decide if it is worth surrendering the benefits of certain traits for the benefits of others.
Changing a personality trait is NOT an easy task, but at least now you know what you're looking for.

I used to be like that as well OP. What seems to work for me is what I think is called "spaced repetition". Basically, reading what you want to study, then repeating it to myself at set intervals. The same applies for exercises as well.

I wish I could help more, but I am not particularly well versed with studying myself too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Set an environment to succeed in studying.

I have massive attention and procrastinating problem, but I got around it this way. No tips or tricks or hardcore iron will to it.

-You must want to do it - Have a reason why you are studying - what will you achieve by doing it?

-Place to do it- You need a place where you can actually concentrate. I abhor studying at home since it is unbelievably easy for me to lose focus. Library functions in the same way a gym does. What the hell are you doing there if not working towards thing you came for? Be done with it and go home once you finish for a day.

-Divide a single big studying goal into small chunks - Do you scale a mountain in one step? Divide your work in easier segments. This works for most things in life.


-Repetition- When yo do come in library or a studying environment of your choosing, you will probably be clueless and unmotivated and feel no point to it. Remember the points before and start working. Bit by bit. You don't have to be effective at first. If at first you are spending 8 hours at book, and only 2 hours are effective of that. That is fine - its called greasing the groove. With time it will ramp up to 6/8, as you get more into it and understand more things. Just make yourself sit and try to pick apart the subject you are studying. At some point, you will feel the subject you are studying familiar and you will become most effective at doing it.

Keep going, you have finally got it.
This applies for studying anything - more interesting or less interesting stuff.

>>28201855
It is understandable. Home is a place to relax. Don't try to make it anything other than that. It's useless and it derives joy from a well earned rest.

Learning this skill will make you a better and more capable person.
Few more points that I didn't mention:

-Give yourself planned time. If you know exams are ahead and you have 6 subjects to study. Start 20 days before the first subject starts. This will make it kind on you and easy for you to finish things in time without stress.

-While studying, do not give a shit about other subjects. Only the one in front of you is important. Only that section/that chapter. Once that is done, move to the next.

-Make it a point to study every single day at that same environment. It doesn't matter if you can't be 8 hours there. Sometimes it will be 2, sometimes 4, sometimes 8. The most important thing is that you are frequent every day at that place. Habits once are powerful once formed (And habits take about one week to form).

Depends. If I have the time, it doesn't matter the scheduling. Sometimes I was 8 AM sharp in library and done by 6 PM. Sometimes I was there at 3 PM and done by midnight. It just mattered that I was coming day after day.
I came whenever I felt ready to come, so no forcing it really other than having to be there.


That was the way I did it for the first two years, but on the third, fourth an fifth year I already started working in my field on the third year, so I had to schedule it since I was working from 8 AM to 4PM. Leaving me with time to study from about 5PM till 10PM. I would usually finish up like that, go sleep and repeat.

That was pretty harsh pace to maintain for 3 years but It helped, since I got out debt free, with insane boost in skills and knowledge compared to my peers.

At 18 I had zero studying skills with huge attention disorder, winging it all my life through school. This is the result of years of trial and error in university and knowing that, I fully believe any person can achieve this given time, effort and will to do it.

Also, library is a great place to focus on other things you want to achieve in your life so feel free to use it for other areas of your life. Read some books anons recommend on this board. Most of them are the condensed version of a persons thoughts through decades, that is shortened down to a few hour read. It can be amazing and life changing to gain those perspectives in such a short time so I advise to give that a go as well, once you finish with your studies.

Just being an autistic maniac works with a couple caveats. You need a few social skills. Mostly just showing interest in others, not rambling, and learning to not be outwardly judgmental of people so long as they are kind (genuinely kind, be as much of a dick as you want to really passive aggressive people). AND you also kinda sorta have your life together (if 25+).. Emphasis on it only needing to be "kinda sorta" though., I basically just mean you don't live with your parents, aren't obese, and you're above the paycheck to paycheck style of living.

The hard part is learning to feel zero embarrassment for being bombastically weird. It doesn't work if you half-ass it. Expect more people to hate you as well, but the benefits are worth it. If you work a job with a lot of social rules, start viewing your job as nothing more than an exchange of time for money and then completely be yourself outside of work. Environments with a lot of social rules are extremely cucked and, as an autist, there is no social success to be found in such environments unless you're okay with having a very submissive personality.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28199437
This is real life, not a 90's family sitcom, or a soap opera. She's never going to learn from her mistakes or genuinely apologize. This is what real life relationships are like, humans are dumb primitive animals with egos. Bad mothers exist, and you have one, accept it. Just like you wouldn't expect a feral dog or a snake to act reasonable, stop expecting your narc parent to.
Narcissists really aren't that interesting. When you truly understand them, you realize they are immature, childish, impulsive, have a low attention span, are addicted to instant gratification and negative ego.
Accept the relationship is what it is. The most empowered thing to do, hypothetically, is embrace conflict. Stop being a wimp. Arguing with her doesn't have to feel bad. Learn to manipulate her and push her buttons. Embrace and cultivate the art of verbal sparring.
I assume you are an adult now. This isn't a mother-child relationship anymore. Treat her like a child or a pet, let go of idealized notions. Your new relationship is about disciplining and training her, not begging for her approval.
It's like the redpill dating philosphy, it applies here too: Dysfunctional women like to be put in their place, overpowering them gives them a sense of security. And they like the attention. Don't see conflict as a failure, to blame yourself for, it's just life, take a page from the book of toxic masculinity. If she's hurt laugh at her: "U mad? ha ha. You're too sensitive, I was just joking, lighten up." Then act like nothing happened. Next time you visit her act like your relationship is perfect. "Oh hi mom, how's the vegetable garden going?" When she brings up old conflicts you say: "Huh? What? Oh mom, you know I love you, stop making a big deal out of nothing." Be dismissive. If she keeps being aggressive, make a joke and call her crazy. Stop trying to be cooperative, and be a power broker instead. If she pushes boundaries, leave, hang up the phone, whatever and try again later.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So.. take a shower, section off your house into zones and tackle a zone per day.

If adhd is your excuse (( I have it too, I was on 240 mg of Ritalin, 60 mg of Adderall and 120 mg of vyvanse at different times before going cold turkey and switching to caffeine while trying for a baby fingers crossed)) I suggest you start the process of looking for treatment. Adhd can also mimic other disorders and or compound.

I have ocd as well. OCD and ADHD surprisingly did not make an incredibly successful, hygienic, high functioning individual.
I did. It's going to feel like you're pretending at first but with each new clean room, each new clean skin day, each new confidence it will feel better and better instead of staring in horror at everything falling down around you.

I mentioned caffeine and it helps me personally, but if you find it helps you stay away from energy drinks as the amount we need will easily give you vitamin poisoning from all the other additives (( hair loss liver failure etc b vitamins arent a joke or pissed out at those values.)) It's cringe af but gfuel works for me in my country.

Baby steps op but you've got to start.
